and daryl lane with this show we're beginning a look at the fascinating writing career of science fiction author charles harness born and raised in texas harness completed his university in law studies in washington dc from 1946 to 1953 harness produced 13 short stories and two novels one of the novels the rose is a classic harness completed law school in 1946 so in those years he was striving to establish a career as a patent lawyer and to support his family right and it was the financial strain confronting his young family that encouraged harness to write science fiction i was working in washington as a mineral economist during the war and going to law school and my daughter was born in 1946 and there were some bills to be paid and we needed the money so i sat down and wrote my first science fiction story which was time trip and this was bought by what was then astounding and i thought well gee do they pay money for this stuff so i thought perhaps i should turn out some more of it which i did so harness cut the writing bug and was able to work full-time and to write for a few years but he did stop writing in 1953 and he wasn't heard from again until 1966 here's what he told us when we asked him about that long gap i wrote for a while until my daughter got old enough to demand more and more of my time so the writing had to come to an end and it didn't really resume again until she was ready to go off to college this was in 1964 and i picked it up again two of these early stories harness published under the pseudonym leonard lockhart the second of the two that professional look was a joint effort between harness and theodore thomas another patent lawyer here harness describes the genesis of these stories and their eventual course ted and i we were in the patent department at sign amid together i wrote the first leonard lockhart story improbable profession and at that time he was writing science articles for the stanford advocate as well as being on the patent in the patent department at sign amid so i said to him why don't you and i start this series of stories about a patent attorney and his problems here's the first one so he said yeah we can do that so i wrote the first one he wrote the second one no together we wrote the second one it was half and half and after that i left sign amid and went to grace and he continued the series so number three is in all subsequent stories or his even though the name leonard lockhart is still used on harness's active writing periods were 1946 to 1953 during which he produced 13 short stories and the two novels flight into yesteryear also publishes a paradox man in the rose 1966 and 1968 with six short stories in the novel the ring of riddernell in 1974 to the present which saw publication of produced in conjunction with odessa college in odessa texas music dydish music e music два are um and and UN Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane. And Bill Vernon. 1953 marked the publication of a little-known science fiction classic, Charles Harness's short novel entitled The Rose. And we have to say little-known because of the curious history of the book. Right. First of all, Harness attempted to sell the book in the United States markets, but the editors were unwilling to buy it. He then had to sell it in England to a relatively obscure magazine, Authentic Science Fiction. My agent at the time, Forrest Ackerman of, I think, Los Angeles, peddled it around here and there. Nobody in this country would buy it. It went to John Camel, and he wrote a nice two-line letter bag. He just couldn't use it. It wasn't the kind of thing that any science fiction magazine or fantasy and science fiction magazine was publishing at the time. And I should have known better for writing it. But I wanted to write it, so I did. And finally, Ackerman sold it to this little Authentic magazine in England, and they published it. Authentic was under the editorship of H.J. Campbell when The Rose was published. Publication of The Rose is considered to be the capstone achievement in the generally mediocre 85-issue run of the magazine. It would have languished in the pages of Authentic were it not for the fact that the British critics absolutely loved it. Arthur Clarke, Judith Merrill, Brian Aldis, and in particular Michael Moorcock praised it. It was through the almost single-handed efforts of Moorcock that The Rose was published in book form, again in England, some years later. Arthur Clarke saw it, Dr. Moorcock saw it. And Moorcock was getting into the editor business over there at that time. Asked to have his people, Compact Books, publish it. And we have a contract for that, and they did publish it. Then it was picked up fairly quickly by two other British outfits in hardcover form. And of course they had to pad it out with the two other stories to make it in a book size. The two short stories added to pad the length of the volume in which The Rose was finally published are The New Reality and The Chess Players. The New Reality, written in 1950 and first published in Thrilling Wonder Stories, is considered to be Harness' finest short story. The Chess Players is a clever little story based on the trouble it develops when a chess club encounters a chess-playing rap. In fact, many of Harness' works allude to chess. We ask him if he enjoys the game. Well, I loved to play it, or at least in other years I did. And I still do. I read a book of chess combinations nearly every night. It puts me to sleep. Various brilliances of some of the past masters. It's an exciting thing. It wasn't until 1969 that The Rose was made available in the United States, thanks to the efforts of Damon Knight. Berkeley published it then, and so far that has been the only American edition. Damon Knight then picked it up from the British. He said, hey, here's the thing I've been thinking about all these many years, and that's come out in Britain. Why didn't you give it to me? So, okay. I sold Berkeley the rights, the U.S. rights to it. And that's why all the time lag. If it hadn't been for Moorcock, it would never have gone anywhere. It struck us that one reason The Rose could not find a United States publisher in 1953 was that American readers simply were not ready for a book heavy on the metaphysical rather than the hardware. We asked Karnas if he might agree. You got a point there. They could live with something like this, whereas over here everybody was guided pretty much by the dean of science fiction, John Camel, and he was a hardware man. And everything had to obey the laws of physics or it would be unacceptable. More about The Rose on our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon. And Daryl Lane. On our last show, we talked with science fiction author Charles Harness about his classic short novel, The Rose. We learned how The Rose was enthusiastically embraced by the British critics. Yet it wasn't published in the United States until 16 years had elapsed from its initial publication in an obscure British magazine. In this show, we'll look at some of the literary aspects of The Rose. Many of Harness's earlier works were written hastily, but, we hasten to add, not clumsily. The Rose, on the other hand, required a considerable length of time for completion. That was one of the stories where I didn't know how it was going to come out. And in fact, I worked on that one for two years, Bill. This is not a two-month job. I read all the books on the arts in the Stanford Public Library. This is one year. I took notes on them for my entire two weeks' vacation one year. And then it gradually began to come together. And I used, of course, as you've seen in the story, Oscar Wilde's story of The Night and Gill and the Rose, which I'd read many years before, and I was quite impressed by it. Harness also filled us in on some other details about the writing of The Rose. For instance, its early incarnations were longer, and it originally had another name. Let me give you a little bit more history on this. There was a time when The Rose was in a longer form, and it had the name, not The Rose, but Invitation. It was an intergalactic thing, where the Earth was being examined to see whether it would be admitted into a galactic brotherhood. And it didn't have the ending that it now has. Damon Knight liked that, but he couldn't get his publishers to accept it. This, again, was a year or so before it came out, and it's inauthentic in its short form, which it tells nothing. So, at that point, I said, maybe I'm going to shorten this thing down, give it a different ending. So, I did. I cut it from 45,000 words down to, I think it's about 30,000. And Ackerman then was able to sell it to the authentic in England. The central theme of The Rose is difficult to capsule. It's a love story involving two central characters, Rui Jacques and Anna Vontal. It's set in the midst of a future confrontation between science and art, and it describes a transcendental evolution of man into Superman. Harness and his brother Billy, who, as we shall learn in a later show, died when Harness was still in high school, were the models for the central characters. Rui Jacques, again, resembles my brother a great deal. And if you can visualize that guy with his sarcasm, his biting wit, his contempt for all the, well, I don't know. But he was a, he had a high personal integrity and a impatience with, with, uh, convention and so on. At least in his head, he did. And I wanted to get him in the print. And, of course, Anna Vontal is me, although I tried to take on a female form to make it effective. I would have, at one time, I was, I would have been pleased to die if it would bring him back. But it, of course, that was just being silly. But it was a thought, and it was a psychic force driving the story. Do yourself a favor. Find a copy of The Rose in your local used bookstore and read it. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The Rose in Your Life The Rose in Your Life The saltwater But it was a gift for us that we're a deadhead. But it was a gift for us that we'd have heard of our ashes. And I wanted to pass this away, let's be it to hold my life now. I want it to be loved, we're always sees so有否- The way, let's help her element, let's Rare children. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane and Bill Vernon. In 1968, Berkeley published Charles Harness' novel, The Ring of Riddernail, his first work to appear in 15 years. It's the story of two brothers, one a lawyer, the other a poet, and a far distant future. Here, Harness, who is himself a lawyer, tells us about the very personal inspiration for the poet. My brother Billy was several years older than I. In fact, he was nine years older than I. And he died when I was just about to graduate from high school. He had tumors of the brain, which in those days were inoperable. Today, it wouldn't be too much trouble to operate if they couldn't do it then. So, I have remembered him. And I have never let him go. And he has been in several of my stories. He was the Ring of Riddernail. He was the brother who was destroyed by the chief bad guy. But his brain was retained. He was the poet. His name was Omer. In 1977, Wolfhead, Harness's fourth novel, came out. It was his first novel in nine years. Wolfhead describes a post-atomic holocaust America and the struggle between various cultures that populate the desolate land. Harness told us that when he wrote Wolfhead, he went against the conventional wisdom that one shouldn't write about certain subjects. I started out writing it. I thought I would do a thing which is frowned upon. You're not supposed to write post-atomic novels. It's really unacceptable. But here seemed to be a good one. A real-life character, Richard Nixon, inspired Harness's characterization of the malevolent leader of the underworld. Well, I thought, gee, here's this guy. He's about to take over the country. Anything he does is okay just because he says so. And I'm going to have a character like that in Wolfhead. So, I put him in there. He was the president of the underworld, and he would come out and rule the upper world, except he didn't. Even the wolf with the title was inspired by a real-life dog. The wolf was modeled at the time on an Alaskan husky dog that lived next door to us. And she and I were great friends, so I thought I'd put her in it. When Harness reminisced about Wolfhead, he told us he was pretty much pleased by it. It's one of my happier efforts. It's not really serious. Well, some of it is. You know, at one time, it had a different ending. Of course, we had to ask Harness about that different ending. Keep in mind that during his writing career, he was a full-time patent attorney. The answer to this question provides an interesting insight into other ways the real world can intrude into fiction. And I have to cough when I think about it. Excuse me while I cough. This is a psycholo... That was a psychological cough. In the original ending, the girl lived. But I got involved in some chemical litigation that I lost. And I was so angry and so disappointed, I said, somebody has to die. So I killed the heroine and wrote some poetry for her benefit so she wouldn't feel too badly about it. And that's the poetry, of course, is in the front and in the back. So that's a little sidelight on that. We'll have more with Charles Harness on our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon. And Daryl Lane. Science fiction author Charles Harness began writing in earnest again in the late 70s, and he produced three novels in short order. The Catalyst is the story of a patent lawyer who works for a chemical company. In this respect, it resembles some short stories Harness wrote a decade earlier, The Alchemist and An Ornament to His Profession. The Catalyst actually started out as a longer, mainstream novel, but Harness, unable to sell it, fixed it up as a science fiction work. His brother figured heavily in this book, too. The Catalyst at one time was a general novel, really about my brother Billy, really about me and my mother, and life in Fort Worth, and life in the Red Light District, and life in the police department. And one of the stories there involved a peculiar whistle, which was derived from Sheep May Safely Graze by Johann Sebastian Bach. But that long version never sold. And I thought, well, I'm not going to let it die. I will convert it to a science fiction book. With all the proper trappings and things you need to call it science fiction, which I did. In 1981, Harness published a novel that was sort of a throwback to his early period galaxy-galloping days. Firebird is made up of early Harness devices, such as a time loop and the rebirth of the cosmos. Here Harness tells us about the basis for the story in Firebird. I'm sure you recognize the basic story here. This is Tristan and Isolde. I don't know whether you go in for Wagner or not, but it is Isolde and Tristan drinking what she thinks is the poison drink, but it's the love of lecture again. And they fall in love. And after that, just about everything parallels the Tristan and Isolde story as you would find it in Wagner's opera, including Death at the Inn. Editor David Hartwell of Pocketbooks also influenced Harness' approach to this novel. In the beginning, when I first wrote David Hartwell of Pocketbooks, I should mention, he is a medieval scholar. This is what he got his Ph.D. in English in. And he was quite familiar with the Tristan legend, a myth. And he found Welsh origins for it. And he had me change the names to look like Welsh names. And he said, make him more of a Renaissance knight. So I put in some chess, which is easy enough. So there was something that looked like a chess game. I worked it into the plot and it came out okay. Predators are never content unless they make their contribution. Harness has retired from his lifelong profession of being a patent attorney. He's recently produced a couple of short stories in a novel and more are in the works. He's a gentleman who, while working full-time, produced a small body of quality science fiction. We asked him how he wishes to be remembered. My request there is, please forget me. Let me sink into oblivion. Let the waves wash up over the sand. And everything disappear. Honest to God. We somehow doubt that Mr. Harness will be forgotten. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas.そう milhões, Runa
